items.body_markdown:
New engineer here, upon updating to 1.1.0, from 1.0.1 some of the test suite broke, it stopped working on RC3 and later. The background of these tests are calling the java file to create a map and populate it with testData used in the test, but after the update the maps are created but null. After reading the manual and Q&A's, I'm was wondering if my predecessor set this method up in a way that was unsupported approach and if so is a simple method for this that you would recommend instead.

the offending background:



    @parallel=false
    Feature: Tests to verify response from Detector Set API
    
      Background:
        # Get api url from karate-config.js
        * url baseUrl
        # This configures the http headers to use admin user for running the tests
        * callonce read('classpath:common/headers/admin-headers.feature')
        * def DetectorSetControllerTest = Java.type('apitests.application.riskdetectors.detectorset.DetectorSetControllerApiTest')
        * def testData = DetectorSetControllerTest.detectorSetTestDataMap

The Java code it is calling:

    public static Map<String, Object> detectorSetTestDataMap = null;
    
        @BeforeAll
        public static void testData() {
            detectorSetTestDataMap = Runner.runFeature(DetectorsCommon.class,
                    "testdata/create-detectorset-test-data.feature",
                    null,
                    true);
        }

Thank you for your work.
items.title: Karate update 1.1.0 changing a background connection with the java runner file
items.body:
New engineer here, upon updating to 1.1.0, from 1.0.1 some of the test suite broke, it stopped working on RC3 and later. The background of these tests are calling the java file to create a map and populate it with testData used in the test, but after the update the maps are created but null. After reading the manual and Q&A's, I'm was wondering if my predecessor set this method up in a way that was unsupported approach and if so is a simple method for this that you would recommend instead.

the offending background:

@parallel=false
Feature: Tests to verify response from Detector Set API

  Background:
    # Get api url from karate-config.js
    * url baseUrl
    # This configures the http headers to use admin user for running the tests
    * callonce read('classpath:common/headers/admin-headers.feature')
    * def DetectorSetControllerTest = Java.type('apitests.application.riskdetectors.detectorset.DetectorSetControllerApiTest')
    * def testData = DetectorSetControllerTest.detectorSetTestDataMap

The Java code it is calling:

public static Map<String, Object> detectorSetTestDataMap = null;

    @BeforeAll
    public static void testData() {
        detectorSetTestDataMap = Runner.runFeature(DetectorsCommon.class,
                "testdata/create-detectorset-test-data.feature",
                null,
                true);
    }

Thank you for your work.

items.title: Combine 2 object lists by index and retain key and value even if there are duplicates
items.body:
Have an object which has 2 lists.
Is there a way I could merge the 2 lists by index and still retain key / values if there is a conflict between the 2 lists?

This is current object with 2 lists. The lists are not always of same length.

{
    "listA": [
        {
            "text": "index 0 list 1 text",
            "icon": "index 0 list 1 icon"
        },
        {
            "text": "index 1 list 1 text",
            "icon": "index 1 list 1 icon"
        }
    ],
    "listB": [
        {
            "text": "index 0 list 2 text"
        },
        {
            "title": "index 1 list 2 title",
            "text": "index 1 list 2 text",
            "icon": "index 1 list 2 icon"
        },
        {
            "title": "index 2 list 2 title 2",
            "text": "index 2 list 2 text 2",
            "icon": "index 2 list 2 icon 2"
        },
        {
            "header": "index 3 list 2 header 2",
            "icon": "index 3 list 2 icon 2"
        }
    ]
}

After merging looking to achieve following. (A new list)

{
    "listC": [
        {
            "text": "index 0 list 1 text",
            "icon": "index 0 list 1 icon",
            "text": "index 0 list 2 text"
        },
        {
            "text":  "index  1 list 1 text",
            "icon":  "index  1 list 1 icon",
            "title": "index  1 list 2 title",
            "text":  "index  1 list 2 text",
            "icon":  "index  1 list 2 icon"
        },
        {
            "title": "index  2 list 2 title 2",
            "text":  "index  2 list 2 text  2",
            "icon":  "index  2 list 2 icon  2"
        },
        {
            "header": "index 3 list 2 header 2",
            "icon":   "index 3 list 2 icon   2"
        }
    ]
}

Understand this is not feasible due to duplicate keys. Thus one thought is to change the names for the keys in list 2 when merging.

Something like key text becomes shortCopy for list 1 and longCopy for list 2.

Thus resulting in:

{
    "shortCopy":  "index 0 list 1 text",
    "icon":  "index 0 list 1 icon",

    "longCopy": "index 0 list 2 text"
}

Is there an elegant way to achieve this via a stream?

Attempted following where I am creating a new object that holds different keys and adding that to a separate list.
Resulting in no conflicts.

Overall the question is, is there a more elegant approach to achieving this? Possibly with a Stream?
As can see, this involved multiple loops and conditionals and the need to create a a new list and object.

Looking for a cleaner solution.

My attempt to achieve this.

MyObj myObj = // some REST call;
List<NewBenefit> newBenefits = new ArrayList<>();

List<InitialBenefit> list1 = myObj.getList1();
List<InitialBenefit> list2 = myObj.getList2();

List<Benefit> newBenefits = new ArrayList<>();

// just adding the list 1 key/values to new list first. 
for (InitialBenefit item : list1) {
    Benefit benefit = new Benefit();
    benefit.setIcon(item.getIcon());
    benefit.setShortCopy(item.getText());
    newBenefits.add(benefit);
}

for (int i = 0; i < list2.size(); i++) {
    // newBenefits list now exists with some objects. 
    // so check if add new object or update keys in existing object
    // within the list
    if (newBenefits.size() > i) {
        Benefit benefit = newBenefits.get(i);
        benefit.setIcon(list2.get(i).getIcon());
        benefit.setLongCopy(list2.get(i).getText());
    } else {
        Benefit benefit = new Benefit();
        benefit.setIcon(list2.get(i).getIcon());
        benefit.setLongCopy(list2.get(i).getText());
        newBenefits.add(benefit);
    }
}

answers.title: java for loop executes extra iteration
answers.body:
There's no need to create nameList as an array for this. You can iterate the propNames set directly:

private static void addProperties(Properties prop) {
    Set<String> propNames = prop.stringPropertyNames();
    for (String propName:  propNames) {
        String propertyValue = prop.getProperty(propName);
        allProp.put(propName, propertyValue);
        loadOldValues(propName, propertyValue);
    }
}

You might also be able to make use of allProp.putAll(prop) rather than iterating through the keys (though this might require restructuring loadOldValues).

I am very confused. Both variables allProp and prop are define outside the routine and they are initialized

private static void addProperties(Properties prop) {

   String propertyValue = null;
   Set<String> propNames = prop.stringPropertyNames();
   String[] nameList = propNames.toArray(new String[15]);
   for (String propName:nameList) {
      propertyValue = prop.getProperty(propName);
       allProp.put(propName, propertyValue);
      loadOldValues(propName, propertyValue);
   }
}

This is the code with print statements.
